title: Ticket #1310: Improving locking reliability of log files
description:
As described in tickets #1108 , locking of log files has been an ongoing problem. To approach a solution for that, the following steps will be implemented:

  • Creating zero-length lock files in tmp folder on local disk only [*Done*]
  • Lock file names will be created by computing a hash value from the real path of the name of the file to be locked, such that the file name is guaranteed to be unique [*Done*]
  • There will exist at most x lock files at a time such that we cannot run into problems by having too many files in one directory [*Done*]
  • The FileLock destructor will delete the file; however, Condor preen should check for forgotten zero-length files, lock them, and delete them periodically

2010-Nov-24 15:47:57 by matt:
From a side discussion -

The lock files will likely be reused due to directory size concerns. A single lock file may require access from multiple users. A possible solution is to store lock files with 0666. The locking is performed with flock(). Setting 0666 provides a point for users to maliciously lock files. Alternatively,

  • hash(file) -> hashvalue gets created as .../uid/ha/sh/value
  • uid is uid of file owner
  • ownership on lockfile (.../value) is uid with permissions 0644 or less
  • permissions on lock may match that of file (if explicit sharing is desirable) - stretch goal

Problems -

  • source file changes ownership and the lockfile (.../uid/ha/sh/value) does not
  • mirroring permissions, source file changes perms and lockfile does not

2010-Dec-08 13:22:27 by matt:
Question - how does this code behave in cases where the target is removed, say between or during lock calls? what about if the target is recreated?

2010-Dec-08 13:37:58 by cweiss:
What's your definition of "target"? The log file the lock is held for, or the actual lock file? (In the old code they are the same file -- with the local locks they are not.)

2010-Dec-08 13:43:27 by matt:
target as the file the lock is held for, lock(target) -> lockfile = hash(target), lock(lockfile). The "file" in our 24 Nov discussion.

2010-Dec-08 13:52:06 by cweiss:
The lock file object does not track deletion of the origin. If the origin were to be deleted and recreated between lock calls, it would not matter - it does not hold a reference to the origin's fd -- the only reference it has is a file name. Also it never stats the origin.

The instantiating code would be responsible for updating the lock file in case this were necessary (in case of a rename of the origin).

2010-Dec-16 08:17:56 by matt:
Cathrin - Could the cleanup code also cleanup the condorLocks dir? It looks like the construction code will recreate it.

Thought from premature optimization-ville, it may be more efficient to mkdir+open from right to left. Of course, that would assume sharing, which is probably undesirable. Or mkdir until EEXIST and then try open, which would reduce open calls in the common case of no sharing.

2010-Dec-16 12:25:00 by matt:
NOTE: The hash algorithm appears to be an enhancement on SDBM that generates a string between 6 and 10 characters in length (in a buffer that's 256 chars). The length could not be < 5 characters else it would not be separable for dir names.

2010-Dec-16 13:23:56 by cweiss:
Just a few comments on the comments:

  • Yes, I can include the condorLocks dir.
  • Doing the directory creation from right to left will double the number of calls to mkdir if the directories do not exist. I already considered that (also the "repeat until you hit EEXIST and then go back from there"). I'm not sure what is the best way to go -- each option is optimal for some scenarios and suboptimal for others.
  • re: hash algorithm, yup, improved SDBM (as used in Berkeley DB) with low collision rate. I did not spent much thought on the length of the hash value, just wanted to make sure the number of character is in fact larger than 5. 256 positions is overkill -- that can be changed too.

2010-Dec-16 13:59:17 by matt:

2010-Dec-16 16:27:30 by matt:
FileLock::Obtain will return false on an error, indicating the lock attempt failed.

Obtaining a lock -

lock or except - condor_master, condor_job_router, ReadUserLog::Lock (all but readEventOld)
try lock and ignore - ReadUserLog::readEventOld (lots of: if locked then release), WriteUserLog::doWriteEvent
try lock and log - condor_preen, WriteUserLog::*Global* (EVENT_LOG write attempts skipped, log messages aren't all useful)

ReadUserLog::readEventOld is called for all non-XML log reads!
WriteUserLog::doWriteEvent is the common path for writing events!

Open question - does writing an XML entry attempt to lock?

It is dangerous to fail the lock and continue. This situation is not introduced by the new code here. The new code actually introduces 5 attempts, previous code would attempt once. The attempts are safe from signal interrupts.

2010-Dec-17 10:21:37 by bbockelm:
Hi Catherin,

I don't think check-in [19589] always works as advertised. You use "getuid" (if the schedd is started as root, this is always 0); you probably want to use "geteuid" (for the schedd case, this is the user running the job).

For daemon cases like the schedd locking, is it possible to:

  • Have all lock files owned by user "condor".
  • Put in the admin-defined lock directory.

I can understand why these two points wouldn't apply for the case of user submits.

Another note - if you change the hashing algorithm to UID/ab/cd/efg, we would avoid lots of world-writable directories. That would make me more comfortable with the scheme, even if it's at the cost of a significant number of inodes.

Brian

Submitting two jobs with the same UserLog (/tmp/sleep0) results in condor_submit opening and locking /tmp/condorLocks/38/91/500/760032.lockc whereas condor_schedd (run as root) locks /tmp/condorLocks/38/91/0/760032.lockc

2011-Jan-05 16:46:21 by cweiss:
I attached a patch that reintroduces the UID idea: now the effective UID, of course. We don't really ever have the scenario where multiple users (effective UID) write to the same file (as discussed with Todd). Thus it makes sense to have the eUID in there. Additionally, go back to stripping the file's hash value mod 10000, use that value as the first directory value, and then the eUID as a directory value. This will limit the number of directories created to 10000 * number of UIDs. Feel free to apply this patch as appropriate.
